edgeCheckinInterval.label: Poll frequency
edgeCheckinInterval.tooltip: Interval used by this Edge agent to check in with the Portainer instance. Affects Edge environment management and Edge compute features.

associatedEdgeEnvironmentsSelector.info: You can select which environment should be part of this group by moving them to the associated environments table. Simply click on any environment entry to move it from one table to the other.

edgeForm.pingIntervalTooltip: Interval used by this Edge agent to check in with the Portainer instance
edgeForm.snapshotIntervalTooltip: Interval used by this Edge agent to snapshot the agent state
edgeForm.commandIntervalTooltip: Interval used by this Edge agent to fetch commands from the Portainer instance

auth_style_field.label: Auth Style
auth_style_field.tooltip: Auth Style specifies how the endpoint wants the client ID & client secret sent.

edge_compute_settings.title: Edge Compute settings
edge_compute_settings.enable_tip: Enable this setting to use Portainer Edge Compute capabilities.
edge_compute_settings.portainer_url_tooltip: URL of this Portainer instance that will be used by Edge agents to initiate the communications.
edge_compute_settings.enforce_edge_id: Enforce use of Portainer generated Edge ID
edge_compute_settings.enforce_edge_id_tooltip: This setting only applies to manually created environments.

deployment_sync_options.title: Deployment sync options
deployment_sync_options.default_values_tip: Default values set here will be available to choose as an option for edge environment creation
deployment_sync_options.default_poll_frequency_tooltip: Interval used by default by each Edge agent to check in with the Portainer instance. Affects Edge environment management and Edge compute features.
deployment_sync_options.edge_agent_ping_frequency_tooltip: Interval used by default by each Edge agent to ping the Portainer instance. Affects Edge environment management and Edge compute features.
deployment_sync_options.edge_agent_snapshot_frequency_tooltip: Interval used by default by each Edge agent to snapshot the agent state.
deployment_sync_options.edge_agent_command_frequency_tooltip: Interval used by default by each Edge agent to execute commands.

settings_open_amt.title: Intel OpenAMT
settings_open_amt.enable_tip: When enabled, this will allow Portainer to interact with an OpenAMT MPS API.
settings_open_amt.mps_password_tooltip: Needs to be 8-32 characters including one uppercase, one lowercase letter, one base-10 digit, and one special character.
settings_open_amt.domain_name_tooltip: Enter the FQDN associated with the provisioning certificate (e.g., amtdomain.com).
settings_open_amt.certificate_file_tooltip: Supported CAs are Comodo, DigiCert, Entrust, and GoDaddy. The certificate must contain the private key. On AMT 15-based devices, you need to use SHA2.
settings_open_amt.certificate_password_tooltip: Needs to be 8-32 characters including one uppercase, one lowercase letter, one base-10 digit, and one special character.

internal_auth.allow_weak_passwords_message: You have set an insecure minimum password length. This could leave your system vulnerable to attack, are you sure?
internal_auth.information_description: When using internal authentication, Portainer will encrypt user passwords and store credentials locally.
internal_auth.password_rules_description: Define minimum length for user-generated passwords.

application_settings_form.caching_tip: Enabling front-end data caching can mean that changes to Kubernetes clusters made by other users or outside of Portainer may take up to five minutes to show in your session. This caching only applies to Kubernetes environments.
application_settings_form.enable_caching_label: Enable front-end data caching for Kubernetes environments

table_actions.confirm_delete: Do you want to remove the selected access token(s)? Any script or application using these tokens will no longer be able to invoke the Portainer API.

helm_repository.title: Helm repositories
helm_repository.user_description: Adding a Helm repo here only makes it available in your own user account's Portainer UI. Helm charts are pulled down from these repos (plus the globally-set Helm repo) and shown in the Create from Manifest screen's Helm charts list.

defaultRegistryAction.hideTooltip: This hides the option in any registry dropdown prompts but does not prevent a user from deploying anonymously from Docker Hub directly via YAML. Note: Docker Hub (anonymous) will continue to show as the ONLY option if there are NO other registries available to the user.
defaultRegistryAction.showTooltip: This reveals the option in any registry dropdown prompts. (but note that the Docker Hub (anonymous) option only shows if there is no credentialled Docker Hub option available to the user).

deleteButton.confirmMessage: These {{registriesMsg}} might be used by applications inside one or more environments. Removing the {{registriesMsg}} could lead to a service interruption for the applications using them. Do you want to remove the selected {{registriesMsg}}?

deploymentOptionsSection.allowManifestUrl: Allow specifying of a manifest via a URL

backupSettings.title: Back up Portainer
backupSettings.description: This will back up your Portainer server configuration and does not include containers.

sslSettings.title: SSL certificate
sslSettings.forceHTTPSWarning: Forcing HTTPS only will cause Portainer to stop listening on the HTTP port. Any edge agent environment that is using HTTP will no longer be available.
sslSettings.provideNewCertificate: Provide a new SSL Certificate to replace the existing one that is used for HTTPS connections.
sslSettings.certificateTooltip: Select an X.509 certificate file, commonly a crt, cer or pem file.
sslSettings.keyTooltip: Select a private key file, commonly a key, or pem file.

helmCertPanel.description: Provide an additional CA file containing certificate(s) for HTTPS connections to Helm repositories.
helmCertPanel.caFileTooltip: Select a CA file containing your X.509 certificate(s), commonly a crt, cer or pem file.

hiddenContainers.description: You can hide containers with specific labels from Portainer UI. You need to specify the label name and value.

AUTH.LOGIN_WELCOME: Welcome back! Please enter your details

ENDPOINT_ADMIN.NAME: Environment administrator
ENDPOINT_ADMIN.DESCRIPTION: Full control of all resources in an environment

OPERATOR.NAME: Operator
OPERATOR.DESCRIPTION: Operational Control of all existing resources in an environment

HELPDESK.NAME: Helpdesk
HELPDESK.DESCRIPTION: Read-only access of all resources in an environment

READ_ONLY.NAME: Read-only user
READ_ONLY.DESCRIPTION: Read-only access of assigned resources in an environment

STANDARD.NAME: Standard user
STANDARD.DESCRIPTION: Full control of assigned resources in an environment

USER_DETAILS.TITLE: User details
USER_DETAILS.ADMINISTRATOR_TOOLTIP: Administrators have access to Portainer settings management as well as full control over all defined environments and their resources.
USER_DETAILS.DELETE_CONFIRM: Do you want to remove this user? This user will not be able to login into Portainer anymore.
USER_DETAILS.CONFIRM_RENAME: Are you sure you want to rename the user {{oldUsername}} to {{username}}?

USER_AUTH_LOGS.TITLE: User authentication logs
USER_AUTH_LOGS.RETENTION_INFO: Portainer user authentication logs have a maximum retention of 7 days.

AUTO_USER_PROVISION.TITLE: Automatic user provisioning
AUTO_USER_PROVISION.LABEL: Automatic user provisioning
AUTO_USER_PROVISION.DESCRIPTION: With automatic user provisioning enabled, Portainer will create user(s) automatically with a standard user role and assign them to team(s) matching LDAP group name(s). If disabled, users must be created in Portainer beforehand.

LDAP.GROUP_BASE_DN_TOOLTIP: The distinguished name of the element from which the LDAP server will search for groups.
LDAP.GROUP_MEMBERSHIP_ATTRIBUTE_TOOLTIP: LDAP attribute which denotes the group membership.
LDAP.GROUP_FILTER_TOOLTIP: The LDAP search filter used to select group elements, optional.
LDAP.USERS_REMOVAL_SYNC_INFO: Users removal synchronize between groups and teams only available in
LDAP.USERS_REMOVAL_SYNC_TOOLTIP: Groups allows users to automatically be added to Portainer teams. However, automatically removing users from teams to keep it fully in sync is available in the Business Edition.
LDAP.DISPLAY_USER_GROUP_MATCHING_DESC: Show the list of users and groups that match the Portainer search configurations.
LDAP.BASE_DN_TOOLTIP: The distinguished name of the element from which the LDAP server will search for users.
LDAP.USERNAME_ATTRIBUTE_TOOLTIP: LDAP attribute which denotes the username.
LDAP.FILTER_TOOLTIP: The LDAP search filter used to select user elements, optional.
LDAP.DISPLAY_USERS_DESC: Allows you to display users from your LDAP server.
LDAP.AUTO_USER_PROVISION_DESCRIPTION: With automatic user provisioning enabled, Portainer will create user(s) automatically with standard user role and assign them to team(s) which matches to LDAP group name(s). If disabled, users must be created in Portainer beforehand.
LDAP.INFORMATION_DESCRIPTION: When using LDAP authentication, Portainer will delegate user authentication to an LDAP server and fallback to internal authentication if LDAP authentication fails.
LDAP.CONFIGURATION_DESCRIPTION: You can configure multiple LDAP Servers for authentication fallback. Make sure all servers are using the same configuration (i.e. if TLS is enabled, they should all use the same certificates).
LDAP.ADD_SERVER_BUTTON_MESSAGE: Allows you to add an additional LDAP server.
LDAP.ANONYMOUS_MODE_TOOLTIP: Enable this option if the server is configured for Anonymous access.
LDAP.INFO_TEXT: When using LDAP authentication, Portainer will delegate user authentication to an LDAP server and fallback to internal authentication if LDAP authentication fails.
LDAP.MULTIPLE_SERVER_INFO: You can configure multiple LDAP Servers for authentication fallback. Make sure all servers are using the same configuration (i.e. if TLS is enabled, they should all use the same certificates).
LDAP.USE_STARTTLS_TOOLTIP: Enable this option if you want to use StartTLS to secure the connection to the server. Ignored if Use TLS is selected.
LDAP.USE_TLS_TOOLTIP: Enable this option if you need to specify TLS certificates to connect to the LDAP server.
LDAP.SKIP_TLS_VERIFY_TOOLTIP: Skip the verification of the server TLS certificate. Not recommended on unsecured networks.
LDAP.SERVICE_ACCOUNT_PASSWORD_TOOLTIP: If you do not enter a password, Portainer will leave the current password unchanged.
LDAP.SERVICE_ACCOUNT_TOOLTIP: Account that will be used to search for users.

AD.INFORMATION_DESCRIPTION: When using Microsoft AD authentication, Portainer will delegate user authentication to the Domain Controller(s) configured below; if there is no connectivity, Portainer will fallback to internal authentication.
AD.CONFIG_DESCRIPTION: You can configure multiple AD Controllers for authentication fallback. Make sure all servers are using the same configuration (e.g. if TLS is enabled, they should all use the same certificates).
AD.SERVICE_ACCOUNT_TOOLTIP: Account that will be used to search for users.

SSO.TITLE: Single Sign-On
SSO.USE_SSO_TOOLTIP: When using SSO the OAuth provider is not forced to prompt for credentials.
SSO.AUTO_USER_PROVISION_DESC: With automatic user provisioning enabled, Portainer will create user(s) automatically with the standard user role. If disabled, users must be created beforehand in Portainer in order to login.
SSO.AUTO_USER_TEAM_DESC_1: The users created by the automatic provisioning feature can be added to a default team on creation.
SSO.AUTO_USER_TEAM_DESC_2: By assigning newly created users to a team, they will be able to access the environments associated with that team. This setting is optional and if not set, newly created users won't be able to access any environments.
SSO.NO_TEAMS: You have not yet created any teams.
SSO.DEFAULT_TEAM_DISABLED: The default team option will be disabled when automatic team membership is enabled
SSO.TEAM_MEMBERSHIP_DESCRIPTION: Automatic team membership synchronizes the team membership based on a custom claim in the token from the OAuth provider.
SSO.CLAIM_NAME_TOOLTIP: The OpenID Connect UserInfo Claim name that contains the team identifier the user belongs to.
SSO.DEFAULT_TEAM_DESC: The default team will be assigned when the user does not belong to any other team.

AUTHENTICATION.TITLE: Authentication settings
AUTHENTICATION.SESSION_TOOLTIP: Time before users are forced to relogin.
AUTHENTICATION.SESSION_WARNING: Changing from default is only recommended if you have additional layers of authentication in front of Portainer.

OAUTH.USE_SSO_TOOLTIP: When using SSO the OAuth provider is not forced to prompt for credentials.
OAUTH.AUTO_USER_PROVISION_DESC: With automatic user provisioning enabled, Portainer will create user(s) automatically with the standard user role. If disabled, users must be created beforehand in Portainer in order to login.
OAUTH.AUTO_USER_TEAM_DESC_1: The users created by the automatic provisioning feature can be added to a default team on creation.
OAUTH.AUTO_USER_TEAM_DESC_2: By assigning newly created users to a team, they will be able to access the environments associated to that team. This setting is optional and if not set, newly created users won't be able to access any environments.
OAUTH.NO_TEAMS: You have not yet created any teams.
OAUTH.DEFAULT_TEAM_DISABLED: The default team option will be disabled when automatic team membership is enabled
OAUTH.TEAM_MEMBERSHIP_DESCRIPTION: Automatic team membership synchronizes the team membership based on a custom claim in the token from the OAuth provider.
OAUTH.CLAIM_NAME_TOOLTIP: The OpenID Connect UserInfo Claim name that contains the team identifier the user belongs to.
OAUTH.DEFAULT_TEAM_DESC: The default team will be assigned when the user does not belong to any other team
OAUTH.CLIENT_ID_TOOLTIP: Public identifier of the OAuth application
OAUTH.AUTHORIZATION_URL_TOOLTIP: URL used to authenticate against the OAuth provider. Will redirect the user to the OAuth provider login view
OAUTH.ACCESS_TOKEN_URL_TOOLTIP: URL used by Portainer to exchange a valid OAuth authentication code for an access token
OAUTH.RESOURCE_URL_TOOLTIP: URL used by Portainer to retrieve information about the authenticated user
OAUTH.REDIRECT_URL_TOOLTIP: URL used by the OAuth provider to redirect the user after successful authentication. Should be set to your Portainer instance URL
OAUTH.LOGOUT_URL_TOOLTIP: URL used by Portainer to redirect the user to the OAuth provider in order to log the user out of the identity provider session.
OAUTH.USER_IDENTIFIER_TOOLTIP: Identifier that will be used by Portainer to create an account for the authenticated user. Retrieved from the resource server specified via the Resource URL field
OAUTH.SCOPES_TOOLTIP: Scopes required by the OAuth provider to retrieve information about the authenticated user. Refer to your OAuth provider documentation for more information about this
OAUTH.TENANT_ID_TOOLTIP: ID of the Azure Directory you wish to authenticate against. Also known as the Directory ID

USER_SETTINGS.TITLE: User settings
USER_SETTINGS.LDAP_WARNING: You cannot change your password when using LDAP authentication.
USER_SETTINGS.OAUTH_WARNING: You cannot change your password when using OAuth authentication.

THEME.ERROR_UPDATE_MESSAGE: Unable to update user theme settings

HELM_TEMPLATES.HELM_CHART_SELECTION: Select the Helm chart to use. Bring further Helm charts into your selection list via
HELM_TEMPLATES.BETA_FEATURE_MESSAGE: Beta feature - so far, this functionality has been tested in limited scenarios. For more information, see this blog post on Portainer Helm support.
HELM_TEMPLATES.INITIAL_DOWNLOAD_HELM_CHARTS: Initial download of Helm charts can take a few minutes

stack_created_outside_portainer: This stack was created outside of Portainer. Control over this stack is limited.
stack_orphaned_associate_with_environmen: This stack is orphaned. You can re-associate it with the current environment using the 'Associate to this environment' feature.
reassociate_stack_to_current_environment: This feature allows you to re-associate this stack to the current environment.
stack_deployed_using_compose_v2: This stack will be deployed using the equivalent of docker compose. Only Compose file format version 2 is supported at the moment.
stack_deployed_using_compose: This stack will be deployed using docker compose.
compose_file_format_info: You can get more information about Compose file format in the
stack_editor_placeholder: Define or paste the content of your docker compose file here
webhook_tooltip: Create a webhook (or callback URI) to automate the update of this stack. Sending a POST request to this callback URI (without requiring any authentication) will pull the most up-to-date version of the associated image and re-deploy this stack.
prune_services_tooltip: Prune services that are no longer referenced.
confirm_remove_stack: Do you want to remove the stack? Associated services will be removed as well.
confirm_stack_update: Do you want to force an update of the stack?
confirm_detachment_message: Do you want to detach the stack from Git?
confirm_migrate_stack_message: This action will deploy a new instance of this stack on the target environment, please note that this does NOT relocate the content of any persistent volumes that may be attached to this stack.
stop_stack_confirm_message: Are you sure you want to stop this stack?
name_validation_message: This field must consist of lower case alphanumeric characters, '_' or '-' (e.g. 'my-name', or 'abc-123').
stack_type_docker_stack: This stack will be deployed using the equivalent of the docker stack deploy command.
stack_type_docker_compose_v2: This stack will be deployed using docker compose. Only Compose file format version 2 is supported at the moment.
stack_name_standardization_note: Note: Due to a limitation of libcompose, the name of the stack will be standardized to remove all special characters and uppercase letters.
stack_type_docker_compose: This stack will be deployed using docker compose.
upload_instructions: You can upload a Compose file from your computer.
template_load_failed_admin: Custom template could not be loaded, please
template_load_failed_contact_admin: Custom template could not be loaded, please contact your administrator.
define_or_paste_content_here: Define or paste the content of your docker compose file here
more_info_about_compose: You can get more information about Compose file format in the
create_webhook_tooltip: Create a webhook (or callback URI) to automate the update of this stack. Sending a POST request to this callback URI (without requiring any authentication) will pull the most up-to-date version of the associated image and re-deploy this stack.
stack_create_validation_file_empty: Stack file content must not be empty.
error_template_file_retrieve: Unable to retrieve Custom Template file
editor_shortcut_tooltip_windows:
Ctrl+F - Start searching
Ctrl+G - Find next
Ctrl+Shift+G - Find previous
Ctrl+Shift+F - Replace
Ctrl+Shift+R - Replace all
Alt+G - Jump to line
Alt+F - Persistent search:
        Enter - Find next
        Shift+Enter - Find previous
editor_shortcut_tooltip_mac:
Cmd+F - Start searching
Cmd+G - Find next
Cmd+Shift+G - Find previous
Cmd+Option+F - Replace
Cmd+Option+R - Replace all
Option+G - Jump to line
Option+F - Persistent search:
        Enter - Find next
        Shift+Enter - Find previous

stack_env_panel.explanation: You may use {{docLink}} in your compose file. The environment variable values set below will be used as substitutions in the compose file. Note that you may also reference a stack.env file in your compose file. A stack.env file contains the environment variables and their values (e.g. TAG=v1.5).
stack_env_panel.alert_repository: When deploying via Repository, the stack.env file must already reside in the Git repo.
stack_env_panel.alert_web_editor: When deploying via Web editor, Upload, or Custom template deployment, the stack.env file is auto created from what you set below.

advancedMode.simpleModeTip: Switch to simple mode to define variables line by line, or load from .env file

environmentVariablesPanel.helpMessage: Environment changes will not take effect until redeployment occurs manually or via webhook.

gitForm.authExplanation: Enabling authentication will store the credentials and it is advisable to use a git service account
gitForm.tokenTooltip: Provide a personal access token or password

refField.specifyReference: Specify a reference of the repository using the following syntax: branches with
refField.defaultReference: If not specified, will use the default HEAD reference, normally the main branch.

composePathField.indicatePath: Indicate the path to the {{fileType}} file from the root of your repository (requires a yaml, yml, json, or hcl file extension).

public.label: Public
public.description: I want any user with access to this environment to be able to manage this resource

administrators.label: Administrators
administrators.description: I want to restrict the management of this resource to administrators only

restricted.label: Restricted
restricted.description: I want to restrict the management of this resource to a set of users and/or teams

private.label: Private
private.description: I want to restrict this resource to be manageable by myself only

restricted.label: Restricted
restricted.singleTeamDescription: I want any member of my team ({teamName}) to be able to manage this resource
restricted.multipleTeamsDescription: I want to restrict the management of this resource to one or more of my teams

wizard.message: Only do this once for your environment, regardless of how many nodes are in the cluster. You do not need to add each node as an individual environment in Portainer. Adding just one node (we recommend the manager node) will allow Portainer to manage the entire cluster.
